Some strip themselves quite naked when they are going to join battle with the savageS, partly that, being lighter, they may be so much the more expeditious in avoid- ing their adversaries’ weapons, partly, that they may appear to despise wounds. In long jour- nies, they generally go bareheaded amidst rain, heat‚ and wind. Some, however, tie a piece of red woollen cloth round their forehead‚ which is a great defence against the heat of the sun andspains in the head. They greatly prize a European hat, especially the young men, who likewise are much delighted with Spanish saddles, with spurS, and iron bridles.
